nodes.html: How does the information in GO-CAMs compare to existing pathway databases?

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63

nodes.html: GO-CAMs are causally connected GO annotations. Existing pathway databases are not explicitly geared for performing GO annotation, although some such as Reactome include GO terms.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 5.35
Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63

nodes.html: GO-CAMs differ from databases such as BioModels because the information in a GO-CAM is qualitative, whereas the information in BioModels is quantitative.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63
Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63
Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63

nodes.html: GO-CAMs have a different model from many pathway databases, which is shown below:

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 5.35
Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63

nodes.html: The GO-CAM model is activity-centric, in that the molecular activity (i.e. GO molecular function) is the central unit of annotation.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63
Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63

nodes.html: The model allows for standard GO annotations (with no causal connection), or for causally connected annotations. This allows for the capture of partial information in an incremental fashion.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 12.63

nodes.html: The GO-CAM model is simpler than that used by databases such as Reactome: in a GO-CAM we do not typically capture all the participants in a reaction, together with their stoichiometry. Instead this information is included in the GO term.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: The GO-CAM model is activity-centric, in that the molecular activity (i.e. GO molecular function) is the central unit of annotation.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: The model allows for standard GO annotations (with no causal connection), or for causally connected annotations. This allows for the capture of partial information in an incremental fashion.
